questions.prompt: The analysis equation of the Exponential Fourier Series is:
options: C) X_k = T₀ ∫_{T₀} x(t) e^{-jkω₀t} dt
questions.explanation: The analysis equation is X_k = (1/T₀) ∫_{T₀} x(t) e^{-jkω₀t} dt. Note: (1) the 1/T₀ normalisation factor, (2) the minus sign in the exponent, and (3) the integral is over one complete period T₀, not from -∞ to ∞ (that would be the Fourier Transform).

questions.prompt: The synthesis equation reconstructs x(t) as:
options: D) x(t) = T₀ Σ X_k e^{-jkω₀t}
questions.explanation: The synthesis equation is x(t) = Σ_{k=-∞}^{∞} X_k e^{+jkω₀t}. The plus sign in the exponent is the opposite of the analysis equation. There is no 1/T₀ factor — that factor already appeared in the analysis equation when computing X_k.

questions.prompt: If X_k are the FS coefficients of x(t), then X₀ equals:
options: A) The peak value of x(t)
B) The RMS value over one period
C) The average value of x(t) over one period
D) Zero for all real signals
questions.explanation: X₀ = (1/T₀)∫_{T₀} x(t) dt, which is the average (mean) value of x(t) over one period. When k=0, the exponential e^{-j·0·t} = 1, so the integral becomes a plain average.

questions.prompt: The orthogonality property used in deriving the analysis equation states that ∫_{T₀} e^{j(m-k)ω₀t} dt equals:
options: A) T₀ for all m and k
B) 0 for m ≠ k; T₀ for m = k
C) 1 for m ≠ k; 0 for m = k
D) π for m ≠ k; 2π for m = k
questions.explanation: When m ≠ k, the integrand e^{j(m-k)ω₀t} is a complex exponential at a non-zero harmonic frequency. Its integral over a complete period is zero (positive and negative areas cancel). When m = k, e^{j·0·t} = 1, so the integral equals T₀.

questions.prompt: The sign convention for the EFS pair is:
options: A) Both analysis and synthesis use +jkω₀t
questions.explanation: Analysis: e^{−jkω₀t} (minus). Synthesis: e^{+jkω₀t} (plus). This sign convention is analogous to the Fourier Transform pair. The minus sign in analysis 'demodulates' the k-th harmonic; the plus sign in synthesis 'remodulates' it.

questions.prompt: When integrating to find X_k, you may integrate over:
options: C) Any contiguous interval of length T₀
questions.explanation: The periodicity of x(t) means that the integral over any contiguous interval of length T₀ gives the same result. Choose the interval that simplifies the calculation — for symmetric signals, [−T₀/2, +T₀/2] is often easiest.

questions.prompt: As |k| → ∞, the Fourier Series coefficients |X_k| of a finite-power periodic signal:
questions.explanation: |X_k| → 0 as |k| → ∞ for signals with finite power. This means higher harmonics contribute less and less, which is why truncating the series to a finite number of terms still gives a reasonable approximation.

options: A) The exponential decay of FS coefficients
B) The ~9% overshoot near discontinuities that persists regardless of how many harmonics are used
C) The convergence of the FS to the average at discontinuities
D) The orthogonality of complex exponentials
questions.explanation: The Gibbs phenomenon is the persistent ~9% overshoot that occurs near discontinuities in a signal when reconstructed using a finite Fourier Series. Adding more terms makes the overshoot narrower but not smaller — it is an inherent limitation of Fourier approximation of discontinuous signals.

questions.prompt: For a periodic signal with ω₀ = 10 rad/s, the frequency of the 3rd harmonic is:
questions.explanation: The k-th harmonic is at frequency kω₀. So the 3rd harmonic is at 3 × 10 = 30 rad/s. The fundamental is at 10 rad/s, 2nd harmonic at 20 rad/s, 3rd at 30 rad/s, etc.

questions.prompt: If x(t) is real and periodic, which statement about X_k is always true?
options: B) X_k is always purely imaginary
questions.explanation: For real signals, the FS coefficients satisfy conjugate symmetry: X_{−k} = X_k*. This means |X_{−k}| = |X_k| (magnitude is even) and ∠X_{−k} = −∠X_k (phase is odd). X_k need not be real unless the signal is also even.
